comments.commentBody: The fact that an author didn't intend an interpretation is no indication that it's not true. Artists create by way of their subconscious, and they are no more able to interpret what their work "really* means than anyone else.

All privatizing does is replace state workers who make a decent salary, with lesser paid private workers and send the savings  to a CEO. Oh, and give the state less control over the employees. We should have learned that lesson by now.

I was living in Tallahassee for a few years when Jeb Bush was governor. I remember his slashing state jobs and privatising them for, he said, a fraction of the cost, but it didn't turn out that way. He called his slash and burn program "People First", though it appeared to some that it was really no more than an excuse to replace decently paid and well trained state employees with poorly trained private employees making a fraction of the amount as their predecessors. I remember the identity theft that occurred under his watch as the new private and poorly paid/poorly educated people (who took the now privatised state jobs), stole information about state employees in order to commit identity theft. I also remember when he tried to shut down the state library, in order to shift the academic collections all over the state, that a ring of librarians locked hands around the state library to prevent this from happening. These librarians actually amounted to one of his few defeats. He may be "more moderate" than his brother, but I doubt his principals have changed much, i.e.,drastically slash government spending (meaning jobs -- people) so as to privatise and poorly pay as many as possible. After all, the Florida elite retirees and ultra rich supposedly make up the difference because many rich people want to live in what he called "Paradise." And yes, it really is lushly scenic in Tallahassee, as in many parts of Florida.

As to the poor and middle class, well, who cares?

"not long after grand juries failed to indict the police officers who killed unarmed black men in Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island,"

I simply don't understand the comparisons of Ferguson to Staten Island. In Staten Island, a truly helpless person (once he couldn't breath) was killed. In Ferguson, a very large man attacked a police officer (the evidence clearly shows that Brown was in the police officer's car. It would make no sense for the police officer to pull Brown in because the officer's gun was on him in the car.) Although Brown was technically unarmed, he was very large and could have easily inflicted grave bodily harm on the police officer and, who, the evidence shows, intended to harm the police officer.

No progress on the issue of police abuse of innocent citizens can be made until there is a factual separation of those who pose no threat to the police and those who truly threaten the police. Ultimately, what happened to Brown was tragic, but his own aggressive behavior played a substantial role in his death. Ferguson and Staten Island are very different situations.

JD

I am a white Canadian and have 3 boys, 20, 17 and 15. The older two are big kids, 6'3" and solid. One thinks he's a rapper.

And I tell them, frequently, exactly what the author tells her son:

"Always address police officers as “sir” or “ma’am.” Do not make any sudden moves, even to reach for identification. Do not raise your voice, resist or run."

I do not give that advice because police are our "friends", even though my interactions with them so far have always been professional. I do that because the police can be dangerous.

Policemen are aggressive people surrounded by violence. Young men of colour may be at greater risk, but white kids with attitude die too.

You will be fine if you just don't resist arrest. No policeman is trying to murder you. He is just doing his job. If you fight him, he will win. Don't listen to you father. He is just making excuses for bad behavior.
Many Americans have “jumbled” heritages that make them think about these questions.

As a mother of two, my heart breaks for you that you have to look at your sweet baby and feel these (legitimate) fears, especially given the loss of his father. As the mother of two -white- girls, I am angry about the history that gives me the privilege not to share those specific fears.

I often read parents' essays online and think how their kid(s) may cringe when they read it someday, but I think this piece will only make your son proud, of both his mother and his father.

'Artists create by way of their subconscious, and they are no more able to interpret what their work "really* means than anyone else.'

That is true!
And now I'm really sorry that I wrote such a silly thing.

I hope Mr. Baesemann will accept my apology - as my consciousness mistakenly got ahold of my subconsciousness?

"Teaching your children how to act around police is pretty much common sense and doesn’t change according to race."
___________
The issue is that the police seem to be much quicker on the trigger when Black males are perceived to be a threat, compared to white males. So the consequences of real or imagined misbehavior are much greater for Black males.

"Everyone pretty much feels the same under such circumstances."

No.

White people who aren't engaged in dangerous criminal activity at the time of being stopped don't generally feel like this encounter could conclude with their being injured or killed. Given recent American history, that attitude is well-founded.

How is it that black people think white people don’t have issues when stopped by the police. Could not be further from the truth. Everyone pretty much feels the same under such circumstances. When stopped by police white people who want the experience to go as well as possible are polite, contrite, scarred, nervous, insulted, intimidated. Every emotion black people have. Teaching your children how to act around police is pretty much common sense and doesn’t change according to race.
But if black people are going to use Michael Brown as an example of anything other than a criminal acting like criminal then they will have trouble.

Disgusting! Unbelievable! These clowns look into the camera out at us and they know the future and they know we do not count in that future, except as fools who will not vote in our own collective best interests. They know we will again let our Congress get away with bailing them out of the Inevitable Second Meltdown.

Hasn't Jamie Dimon yet proved to everyone paying attention his incompetence at running J.P.Morgan Chase? What gall he has in calling legislators for repeal of the derivatives rule. Is this because he understands derivatives so well? Wasn't it derivatives (collateralized debt obligations, credit default swaps, bogus AAA-ratings, robo-signings, decreased capital requirements, special legislation to prevent regulation by our regulatory agencies) that caused even banks not to trust each other which in turn caused our credit markets to seize up? How soon we forget the resulting layoffs, the bailouts, the losses by public entities, and private savers, whose money disappeared.

This cadre of derivatives traders make the Mafia look like petty thieves.

Meanwhile, while we refuse to vote the bums out because we're so disgusted with them, turnout at the polls was the lowest in 72 years. If we don't vote to save our democracy, our economy, these clowns will continue to raise an expensive toast to the gullibility of the 99% of the people of this once-great country.

The claim that US and European unemployment statistics can’t be compared and that the US agencies are publishing unrealistic numbers is incorrect. All of the statistical agencies (and especially the BLS) are aware of the measurement differences, and at least this agency http://www.conference-board.org/ilcprogram/index.cfm?id=19670 publishes data adjusting European unemployment numbers to US employment definitions. With a couple of exceptions the numbers very close.

For example, in October the restated rate for Italy was 13.4 instead of the published rate of 13.2, for Germany 5.0 instead of 4.9; for France 10.0 instead of 10.4. Only the Netherlands (6.5 vs 8.0) and Canada (5.6 vs 6.5) were significantly different (source for the unadjusted rate is tradingeconomics.com).

This continual claim that US statistics are 1.) stupid and simplistic or 2.) devious and mendacious is very corrosive, and leaves the door open for all sort of crackpots to say anything they want and be believed (Shadowstats immediately comes to mind, but there are plenty of others).

I underwent a race transplant by moving to the USA (here I am considered "whilte"); when I go back to the country of my birth I again am on the "other side", at least when I am among older people and way out in the countryside where pretty much only whites live. I conduct myself somewhat differently in each country. So I understand your dilemma.

To me my ecperience simply reinforces the important point that we each are who we truly are: our comportment and character determine our identity. Certainly, no man is an island; we cannot escape the social concensus reality. But your son will be Black, as well as black, his whole life; yet he has an opportunity to transcend both of those labels as well and be himself. Why deny him this opportunity to live in the future?

Bruce Sterling once said "The future is already here. It’s just not evenly distributed yet." Your son can choose to be an ambassador for a post-racial future simply by being. He doesn't need the burden of some explicit action.

Of course people still make cutting racial remarks; if they are a stranger I just shrug it off (I am admittedly lucky I have that opportunity) but if they are a coworker or teammate eventually at some point they realize I am "one of those people" and I know in at least in some cases it has made them change their mind. I don't try rub anyone's nose in it or really do anything. Your son can end up being such an influencer, if he chooses to do so, changing one person at a time.

"Always address police officers as “sir” or “ma’am.” Do not make any sudden moves, even to reach for identification. Do not raise your voice, resist or run."

This is a good start to begin the discussion on how to handle one’s self when stopped by police officers, yet something is lacking. Why exclude the following, which will probably be the most prevalent part of the same conversation:
“Do not be a wise ass” and most important “obey” all instructions from the officer. By not obeying a police officer’s instructions sends negative messages to the police. First, is the lack of respect for their authority and second, heightening their suspicion of some type of guilt.

Every parent needs and must have the same discussion.
How many parents even today never have this discussion and if they did but in the context of race, which is just on the edge bias.

Second, this just reinforces the notion that just because a police officer stops a young person and because they are not "white" the police officer is going to treat the person differently? This also reinforces negative self-respect, which may manifest into disrespect towards the officer.

That's the same talk caucasian and hispanic parents have with their sons too.  And my father gave me as a white teen growing up in some tough neighborhoods in Philly.  It worked for me: "Always address police officers as “sir” or “ma’am.” Do not make any sudden moves, even to reach for identification. Do not raise your voice, resist or run." Makes sense.  It's a good talk.

From Time Wise, whose analysis I trust:

"Despite claims by right-wingers (both mainstream and overtly white supremacist) that violent crime by African-Americans is out of control — and that blacks are criminally victimizing whites at massive and disproportionate rates — the facts say otherwise. As I show in the below analysis:
* Only about 1 percent of African Americans — and no more than 2 percent of black males — will commit a violent crime in a given year;
* Even though there are more black-on-white interracial crimes than white-on-black interracial crimes, this fact is not evidence of anti-white racial targeting by black offenders. Rather, it is completely explained by two factors having nothing to do with anti-white bias: namely, the general differences in rates of criminal offending, and the rates at which whites and blacks encounter one another (and thus, have the opportunity to victimize one another). Once these two factors are “controlled for” in social science terms, the actual rates of black-on-white crime are lower than random chance would predict;
* No more than 0.7 percent (seven-tenths of one percent) of African Americans will commit a violent crime against a white person in a given year, and fewer than 0.3 (three-tenths of one percent) of whites will be victimized by a black person in a given year;"

Read the rest at:

http://www.timwise.org/2013/08/race-crime-and-statistical-malpractice-ho...

I agree that both interracial murders and police homicides are rare. As you indicate, one could argue that the number of interracial murders are so small that no one should be protesting.
About 0.0003 percent of black males will die during a police encounter, but the number of black males who die in controversial police shootings is much smaller. The "victims" are usually armed and often die in an exchange of gunfire. But the assertion is that whites and especially white police target black males. This is why tens of thousands of protestors are marching. However, the claim that whites are waging a "war against black males" is absurd. The reality is that Africans Americans are much likely to kill whites than whites are to kill blacks. It's not just a matter of percentages. Although African Americans make up just 13 percent of the population, they commit the majority of interracial murders.

White parents also have "the talk." The majority of police shooting victims are white. Vox.com that 52 percent of fatal police shooting victims are white, 31 percent are black and 12 percent are Hispanic. Blacks make up only 13 percent of the population, but the racial disparity in police shootings is consistent with the racial disparity in violent crime rates. For example, the racial disparity in fatal police encounters. The FBI Uniform Crime Report show that blacks killed 51.2 percent of the 78 police officers murdered during 2013. (Forty of the cop killers were black, 30 were white (including Hispanics), and 2 were Asian/Pacific Islander. Race was not reported for 2 offenders.) White cops made up 88.5 percent of the murdered officers.

White parents also have "the talk" with their children about not venturing into black neighborhoods. Blacks are quicker than whites on the interracial trigger finger. The racial disparity in interracial murders that don’t involve cops is greater than the disparity in fatal police shooting. The FBI Uniform Crime Report (Expanded Homicide Data Table 6) shows that 409 blacks killed whites while 189 whites (including Hispanics) killed blacks in 2013. Blacks committed 68 percent of interracial murders. Interracial murders make up only a tiny percent of homicides, but they are more numerous than fatal police shootings.

http://www.fbi.gov/about-us/cjis/ucr/ucr

This is a heartbreaking story. The nation has lost its way toward a color-blind future, and we have lost our courage as individuals. Hiding behind militarized police forces and overarming our society so that guns are everywhere, we have traded in our aspirations for "liberty and justice for all" so that a privileged segment of society can keep their illusion of absolute safety.

Helen Keller wrote "Security is mostly a superstition. It does not exist in nature, nor do the children of men as a whole experience it". Certainly the young man who is the subject of this article does not experience it. It is time that we all ask ourselves how we would feel were we in his shoes. And if the answer is that we would choose to pretend to be white, then we have a lot of work to do to build a society that truly provides liberty and justice for all.

Ms. Canedy -- I for one am very, very sorry that you have to have this "talk" with your son Jordan.  It is not right nor just that you should have to, but many of us will deeply appreciate the clarity of your explanation as to why it must happen.  I only hope that we develop enough decency as a people so that this "talk" is no longer necessary at least by the time Jordan has children of his own.

Can I just pass as white? Can I just change my color whenever I wanted to? Most whites don't seem to realize how good they have it. It is a great privilege being white. Black like me??? Most whites have no idea.

This struck a chord with me as well because of our own family makeup growing up. I'm the daughter of a white Jewish mother and Black father and am mistaken for white constantly. My brother is the same skin tone as I do but my sister is a bit darker and her hair has a slightly different texture. I wish that I was darker. I feel biracial (which is what I am) but I don't look it.

It took me 45 years to come to terms with the fact that I am going to be considered white because that's how the world sees me. I can't stand it, in fact I hate it, but that's life. My father grew up in a time before the Civil Rights movement, so he never gave me that Black pride. I had to find it on my own by reading James Baldwin and Malcolm X.

So I turned my life into a positive. I'm in my 50s now. I changed careers and am now an educator, helping Black and Hispanic children (and those of other races). I am learning to speak Spanish, I am finding books with Black characters, I am trying to make children enjoy books by reading to them.

Years ago, the police stopped my father's car in New England. I was in the front seat. Nothing bad happened but why was he stopped in the first place? Did they see a white "woman" in the front seat (me) or in the back (my mother)?

This is America, so the struggle continues.

This piece struck a cord with me. I don't have children yet, but my husband and I plan to start soon. I'm Dominican-American, with a complexion much like the author's. My husband is the son of a white Jewish mother and a black father. He's been mistaken for white on countless occasions.

One of my biggest fears is having sons of different shades and having to give them a version of "the talk" where we have to explain how and why they'll be treated differently by police (and others) based on their skin tone. Somehow I don't think this is the type opportunity my grandparents uprooted their and their children's lives for.

I have rarely felt such heartache for a mother -- a Black mother, whose Black husband died too soon, and now this.  Understandable in her child -- even if only to survive.  But, oh my.  The insidious legacy of slavery.

The Flyin' Hawai'ian is Shane Victorino! Outfielder for the Boston Red Sox!

Or aren't we allowed to mention the Bosox in the New York Times?

"The Flyin' Hawaiian" is not just a standout as a football player, but even more so as a person.  Marcus, you represent your American Samoa-Hawaiian culture, your family and the Duck family impeccably.  Aloha and Maholo, Marcus.  Deep, abiding mahalo.

You got it right, it is a privilege being black; and white and yellow as well; it is a privilege to be human, to be human and alive, to be human and fully alive by sharing basic rights, by being able to enjoy life, to think and speak and do as we please, as long as we do no harm to others. A day may come when we definitely rid ourselves of our ignorance and its prejudices, the color of our skin becoming irrelevant in our social intercourse. I know Martin Luther King would agree. And so would any truly liberated individual from the shackles of hate, bias and tribalism. We all came out of Africa, ethnic differences evolving out of geographic and climate needs ever since. Diversity, the result, which we ought to celebrate.
Blacks and police are like a bull fight. The police are the bulls and the blacks is the matador. The matador provokes the bull and every one is surprised when the bull hooks the matador.

Understandably all blacks are susceptible to humiliation and injustice, but once behind the Trojan wall of class-privilege, the situation gets better for whites and blacks and browns. And mind you, I mean a solid Trojan wall that is relatively unbreachable and stands solid because those who secure class privilege need only to follow the rules of the class to the tee, need only to be subservient to the mandates of the master class.

I would hope that if someone called the police about breaking into my home I would be polite and civil enough to prove that it is my home - Dr. Gates was out of line and the recordings t the recordings  showed that. You have to give respect to get respect -

Ms. Canedy, what a wonderful paen to black dignity under siege at this moment in America. But fear not, your son's dignity is well-protected as long as your son is able to inherit your New York Times-generated class and elite privilege at the top of the Manhattan high rise, within whose confines, as you so humbly say, your son lives protected against the indignity, humiliation and invisibility millions of average Americans undergo everyday. Why? Not simply because they are black, but also because because they are poor. What we are witnessing right now is a class war, not just a race war, with the ultra privileges of the privileged class stacking up against the under-privileges of the rest. If you're black but assimilated into the master class of which the New York Times, among other institutions, are synecdoches, then you are safe.
